sn44.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn44.1:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn44.1:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena khemā bhikkhunī kosalesu cārikaṃ caramānā antarā ca sāvatthiṃ antarā ca sāketaṃ toraṇavatthusmiṃ vāsaṃ upagatā hoti.
sn44.1:1.2.eng: Now at that time the nun Khemā was wandering in the land of the Kosalans between Sāvatthī and Sāketa when she took up residence in Toraṇavatthu.

sn44.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo sāketā sāvatthiṃ gacchanto, antarā ca sāketaṃ antarā ca sāvatthiṃ toraṇavatthusmiṃ ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi.
sn44.1:1.3.eng: Then King Pasenadi was traveling from Sāketa to Sāvatthī, and he too stayed in Toraṇavatthu for a single night.

sn44.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
sn44.1:1.4.eng: Then King Pasenadi addressed a man,

sn44.1:1.5.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, toraṇavatthusmiṃ tathārūpaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā jāna yamahaṃ ajja payirupāseyyan”ti.
sn44.1:1.5.eng: “Please, worthy man, check if there’s a suitable ascetic or brahmin in Toraṇavatthu to whom I can pay homage.”

sn44.1:2.1.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho so puriso rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā kevalakappaṃ toraṇavatthuṃ āhiṇḍanto nāddasa tathārūpaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā yaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo payirupāseyya.
sn44.1:2.1.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man. He searched all over Toraṇavatthu, but he couldn’t see a suitable ascetic or brahmin for the king to pay homage to.

sn44.1:2.2.pli: Addasā kho so puriso khemaṃ bhikkhuniṃ toraṇavatthusmiṃ vāsaṃ upagataṃ.
sn44.1:2.2.eng: But he saw that the nun Khemā was staying there,

sn44.1:2.3.pli: Disvāna yena rājā pasenadi kosalo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ etadavoca:
sn44.1:2.3.eng: so he went to the king and said to him,

sn44.1:3.1.pli: “Natthi kho, deva, toraṇavatthusmiṃ tathārūpo samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yaṃ devo payirupāseyya.
sn44.1:3.1.eng: “Your Majesty, there’s no ascetic or brahmin in Toraṇavatthu for the king to pay homage to.

sn44.1:3.2.pli: Atthi ca kho, deva, khemā nāma bhikkhunī, tassa bhagavato sāvikā arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
sn44.1:3.2.eng: But there is the nun Khemā, who’s a disciple of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

sn44.1:3.3.pli: Tassā kho pana ayyāya evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
sn44.1:3.3.eng: She has a good reputation as being

sn44.1:3.4.eng: astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, and eloquent.

sn44.1:3.5.eng: Your Majesty may pay homage to her.”

sn44.1:4.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena khemā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā khemaṃ bhikkhuniṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo khemaṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavoca:
sn44.1:4.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the nun Khemā, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to her:

sn44.1:4.2.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, ayye, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.1:4.2.eng: “Ma’am, does a realized one still exist after death?”

sn44.1:4.3.eng: “Great king, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.1:4.5.pli: “Kiṃ panayye, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.1:4.5.eng: “Well then, does a realized one no longer exist after death?”

sn44.1:4.6.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.1:4.8.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, ayye, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.1:4.8.eng: “Well then, does a realized one both exist and not exist after death?”

sn44.1:4.9.eng: “This has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.1:4.10.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn44.1:4.11.pli: “Kiṃ panayye, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti.
sn44.1:4.11.eng: “Well then, does a realized one neither exist nor not exist after death?”

sn44.1:4.12.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.1:4.13.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn44.1:5.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, ayye, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, iti puṭṭhā samānā:
sn44.1:5.1.eng: “Ma’am, when asked these questions, you say

sn44.1:5.2.eng: that this has not been declared by the Buddha.

sn44.1:5.4.pli: ‘Kiṃ panayye, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti puṭṭhā samānā:

sn44.1:5.6.pli: na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.1:5.7.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, ayye, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti puṭṭhā samānā:

sn44.1:5.9.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.1:5.10.pli: ‘Kiṃ panayye, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti puṭṭhā samānā:

sn44.1:5.12.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.1:5.13.pli: Ko nu kho, ayye, hetu, ko paccayo yenetaṃ abyākataṃ bhagavatā”ti?
sn44.1:5.13.eng: What’s the cause, what’s the reason why this has not been declared by the Buddha?”

sn44.1:6.1.pli: “Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
sn44.1:6.1.eng: “Well then, great king, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

sn44.1:6.2.eng: What do you think, great king?

sn44.1:6.3.pli: atthi te koci gaṇako vā muddiko vā saṅkhāyako vā yo pahoti gaṅgāya vālukaṃ gaṇetuṃ—
sn44.1:6.3.eng: Do you have any accountant or finger-tallier or reckoner who can count the grains of sand in the Ganges, that is,

sn44.1:6.4.pli: ettakā vālukā iti vā, ettakāni vālukasatāni iti vā, ettakāni vālukasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni vālukasatasahassāni iti vā”ti?
sn44.1:6.4.eng: how many grains of sand there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand?”

sn44.1:6.6.pli: “Atthi pana te koci gaṇako vā muddiko vā saṅkhāyako vā yo pahoti mahāsamudde udakaṃ gaṇetuṃ—
sn44.1:6.6.eng: “Do you have any accountant or finger-tallier or reckoner who can count the water in the ocean, that is,

sn44.1:6.7.pli: ettakāni udakāḷhakāni iti vā, ettakāni udakāḷhakasatāni iti vā, ettakāni udakāḷhakasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassāni iti vā”ti?
sn44.1:6.7.eng: how many gallons of water there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of gallons of water?”

sn44.1:6.10.eng: Because the ocean is deep, immeasurable, and hard to fathom.”

sn44.1:6.11.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yena rūpena tathāgataṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya taṃ rūpaṃ tathāgatassa pahīnaṃ ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
sn44.1:6.11.eng: “In the same way, great king, any form by which a realized one might be described has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn44.1:6.12.pli: Rūpasaṅkhāyavimutto kho, mahārāja, tathāgato gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho—
sn44.1:6.12.eng: A realized one is freed from reckoning in terms of form. They’re deep, immeasurable, and hard to fathom,

sn44.1:6.14.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti.
sn44.1:6.14.eng: To say that after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists: none of these apply.

sn44.1:7.1.pli: Yāya vedanāya tathāgataṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya, sā vedanā tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn44.1:7.2.pli: Vedanāsaṅkhāyavimutto, mahārāja, tathāgato gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho—

sn44.1:7.4.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti.

sn44.1:8.2.pli: yehi saṅkhārehi tathāgataṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya, te saṅkhārā tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn44.1:8.3.pli: Saṅkhārasaṅkhāyavimutto kho, mahārāja, tathāgato gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho—

sn44.1:8.5.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti.

sn44.1:9.1.pli: Yena viññāṇena tathāgataṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya taṃ viññāṇaṃ tathāgatassa pahīnaṃ ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
sn44.1:9.1.eng: consciousness by which a realized one might be described has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn44.1:9.2.pli: Viññāṇasaṅkhāyavimutto kho, mahārāja, tathāgato gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho—
sn44.1:9.2.eng: A realized one is freed from reckoning in terms of consciousness. They’re deep, immeasurable, and hard to fathom,

sn44.1:9.4.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upetī”ti.
sn44.1:9.4.eng: To say that after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists: none of these apply.”

sn44.1:9.5.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo khemāya bhikkhuniyā bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā khemaṃ bhikkhuniṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn44.1:9.5.eng: Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what the nun Khemā said. Then he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled her, keeping her on his right, before leaving.

sn44.1:10.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aparena samayena yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn44.1:10.1.eng: Then on a later occasion King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. He asked the Buddha exactly the same questions he had asked the nun Khemā, and received the same answers.

sn44.1:10.2.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bhante, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?

sn44.1:10.5.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?

sn44.1:10.8.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bhante, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?

sn44.1:10.10.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn44.1:10.11.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?

sn44.1:10.13.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn44.1:10.14.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, bhante, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti puṭṭho samāno:

sn44.1:10.15.pli: ‘abyākataṃ kho etaṃ, mahārāja, mayā—hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi …pe….

sn44.1:10.16.pli: “‘Kiṃ pana, bhante, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti puṭṭho samāno:

sn44.1:10.18.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.1:10.19.pli: Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yenetaṃ abyākataṃ bhagavatā”ti?

sn44.1:11.1.pli: “Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.

sn44.1:11.2.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, atthi te koci gaṇako vā muddiko vā saṅkhāyako vā yo pahoti gaṅgāya vālukaṃ gaṇetuṃ—

sn44.1:11.3.pli: ettakā vālukā iti vā …pe… ettakāni vālukasatasahassāni iti vā”ti?

sn44.1:11.5.pli: “Atthi pana te koci gaṇako vā muddiko vā saṅkhāyako vā yo pahoti mahāsamudde udakaṃ gaṇetuṃ—

sn44.1:11.6.pli: ettakāni udakāḷhakāni iti vā …pe… ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassāni iti vā”ti?

sn44.1:11.10.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, yena rūpena tathāgataṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya, taṃ rūpaṃ tathāgatassa pahīnaṃ ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.

sn44.1:11.11.pli: Rūpasaṅkhāyavimutto kho, mahārāja, tathāgato gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho—

sn44.1:11.14.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti.

sn44.1:12.1.pli: Yena viññāṇena tathāgataṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya, taṃ viññāṇaṃ tathāgatassa pahīnaṃ ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.

sn44.1:12.2.pli: Viññāṇasaṅkhāyavimutto kho, mahārāja, tathāgato gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho—

sn44.1:12.4.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upeti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi na upetī”ti.

sn44.1:13.1.eng: He said, “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!

sn44.1:13.2.pli: Yatra hi nāma satthu ceva sāvikāya ca atthena attho byañjanena byañjanaṃ saṃsandissati, samessati, na virodhayissati yadidaṃ aggapadasmiṃ.
sn44.1:13.2.eng: How the meaning and the phrasing of the teacher and the disciple fit together and agree without contradiction when it comes to the chief matter!

sn44.1:13.3.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ khemaṃ bhikkhuniṃ upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ apucchiṃ.
sn44.1:13.3.eng: This one time I went to the nun Khemā and asked her about this matter.

sn44.1:13.4.pli: Sāpi me ayyā etehi padehi etehi byañjanehi etamatthaṃ byākāsi, seyyathāpi bhagavā.
sn44.1:13.4.eng: And she explained it to me with these words and phrases, just like the Buddha.

sn44.1:13.6.pli: Yatra hi nāma satthu ceva sāvikāya ca atthena attho byañjanena byañjanaṃ saṃsandissati, samessati, na virodhayissati yadidaṃ aggapadasmiṃ.
sn44.1:13.6.eng: How the meaning and the phrasing of the teacher and the disciple fit together and agree without contradiction when it comes to the chief matter!

sn44.1:13.7.eng: Well, now, sir, I must go.

sn44.1:13.8.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

sn44.1:13.9.eng: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”

sn44.1:13.10.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmīti.
sn44.1:13.10.eng: Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn44.10:1.1.pli: Atha kho vacchagotto paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn44.10:1.1.eng: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

sn44.10:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vacchagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn44.10:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn44.10:1.4.eng: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.

sn44.10:1.6.eng: But for a second time the Buddha kept silent.

sn44.10:1.7.pli: Atha kho vacchagotto paribbājako uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
sn44.10:1.7.eng: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta got up from his seat and left.

sn44.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando acirapakkante vacchagotte paribbājake bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn44.10:2.1.eng: And then, not long after Vacchagotta had left, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

sn44.10:2.2.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bhante, bhagavā vacchagottassa paribbājakassa pañhaṃ puṭṭho na byākāsī”ti?
sn44.10:2.2.eng: “Sir, why didn’t you answer Vacchagotta’s question?”

sn44.10:2.3.pli: “Ahañcānanda, vacchagottassa paribbājakassa ‘atthattā’ti puṭṭho samāno ‘atthattā’ti byākareyyaṃ, ye te, ānanda, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā tesametaṃ saddhiṃ abhavissa.
sn44.10:2.3.eng: “Ānanda, when Vacchagotta asked me whether the self survives, if I had answered that ‘the self survives’ I would have been siding with the ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists.

sn44.10:2.4.pli: Ahañcānanda, vacchagottassa paribbājakassa ‘natthattā’ti puṭṭho samāno ‘natthattā’ti byākareyyaṃ, ye te, ānanda, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā tesametaṃ saddhiṃ abhavissa.
sn44.10:2.4.eng: When Vacchagotta asked me whether the self does not survive, if I had answered that ‘the self does not survive’ I would have been siding with the ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists.

sn44.10:2.5.pli: Ahañcānanda, vacchagottassa paribbājakassa ‘atthattā’ti puṭṭho samāno ‘atthattā’ti byākareyyaṃ, api nu me taṃ, ānanda, anulomaṃ abhavissa ñāṇassa uppādāya:
sn44.10:2.5.eng: When Vacchagotta asked me whether the self survives, if I had answered that ‘the self survives’ would that help give rise to the knowledge that

sn44.10:2.8.pli: “Ahañcānanda, vacchagottassa paribbājakassa ‘natthattā’ti puṭṭho samāno ‘natthattā’ti byākareyyaṃ, sammūḷhassa, ānanda, vacchagottassa paribbājakassa bhiyyo sammohāya abhavissa:
sn44.10:2.8.eng: “When Vacchagotta asked me whether the self does not survive, if I had answered that ‘the self does not survive’, Vacchagotta—who is already confused—would have got even more confused, thinking:

sn44.10:2.9.pli: ‘ahuvā me nūna pubbe attā, so etarahi natthī’”ti.
sn44.10:2.9.eng: ‘It seems that the self that I once had no longer survives.’”

sn44.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno ñātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
sn44.11:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.

sn44.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho vacchagotto paribbājako yenāyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sabhiyena kaccānena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn44.11:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to him, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn44.11:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vacchagotto paribbājako āyasmantaṃ sabhiyaṃ kaccānaṃ etadavoca:
sn44.11:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and said to Sabhiya Kaccāna:

sn44.11:1.4.pli: “kiṃ nu kho bho, kaccāna, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.11:1.4.eng: “Worthy Kaccāna, does a realized one still exist after death?”

sn44.11:1.5.eng: “Vaccha, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.11:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bho kaccāna, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.11:1.7.eng: “Well then, does a realized one no longer exist after death?”

sn44.11:1.8.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.11:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bho kaccāna, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.11:2.1.eng: “Well then, does a realized one both exist and not exist after death?”

sn44.11:2.2.eng: “This has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.11:2.3.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn44.11:2.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bho kaccāna, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn44.11:2.4.eng: “Well then, does a realized one neither exist nor not exist after death?”

sn44.11:2.5.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn44.11:2.6.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn44.11:3.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho kaccāna, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:
sn44.11:3.1.eng: “Worthy Kaccāna, when asked these questions, you say that this has not been declared by the Buddha.

sn44.11:3.4.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, bho kaccāna, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

sn44.11:3.6.pli: na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.11:3.7.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho kaccāna, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

sn44.11:3.9.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.11:3.10.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, bho kaccāna, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

sn44.11:3.12.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vadesi.

sn44.11:3.13.pli: Ko nu kho, bho kaccāna, hetu, ko paccayo, yenetaṃ abyākataṃ samaṇena gotamenā”ti?
sn44.11:3.13.eng: What’s the cause, what’s the reason why this has not been declared by the Buddha?”

sn44.11:3.14.pli: “Yo ca, vaccha, hetu, yo ca paccayo paññāpanāya rūpīti vā arūpīti vā saññīti vā asaññīti vā nevasaññīnāsaññīti vā, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjheyya.
sn44.11:3.14.eng: “In order to describe him as ‘formed’ or ‘formless’ or ‘percipient’ or ‘non-percipient’ or ‘neither percipient nor non-percipient’, there must be some cause or reason for doing so. But if that cause and reason were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over,

sn44.11:3.15.pli: Kena naṃ paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya rūpīti vā arūpīti vā saññīti vā asaññīti vā nevasaññīnāsaññīti vā”ti.
sn44.11:3.15.eng: how could you describe him in any such terms?”

sn44.11:3.16.eng: “Worthy Kaccāna, how long has it been since you went forth?”

sn44.11:3.18.pli: “Yassapassa, āvuso, etamettakena ettakameva tampassa bahu, ko pana vādo evaṃ abhikkante”ti.
sn44.11:3.18.eng: “Well, you’ve learned a lot already, let alone what lies ahead!”

sn44.11:4.6.eng: The Linked Discourses on undeclared questions are complete.

sn44.11:5.7.eng: The Book of the Six Sense Fields is finished.
